## Introduction

Welcome to my first blog post! In this article, I'll walk you through how I created this website using Quarto, a powerful open-source scientific and technical publishing system.

## Why Quarto?

As an academic researcher, I needed a platform that could:

- Display my CV in a clean, professional format
- Support a blog for sharing research updates and insights
- Be easy to maintain and update
- Support mathematical notation and code (for future posts)
- Deploy automatically without manual intervention

Quarto checks all these boxes and more!

### 2. Configuration

The `_quarto.yml` file is the heart of the website. It defines:

- The project type (website)
- Navigation structure (navbar with Home and Blog)
- HTML theme and styling options
- Output directory for the rendered site

### 3. Blog Functionality

Quarto's built-in listing feature makes blogging incredibly simple. The `blog.qmd` file uses the `listing` option to automatically display all posts from the `posts/` directory, sorted by date.

Each blog post is a Quarto document (`.qmd` file) with YAML metadata including:

- Title
- Author
- Date
- Categories
- Description

### 4. Automatic Deployment

The real magic happens with GitHub Actions. Every time I push changes to the repository, GitHub automatically:

1. Checks out the code
2. Sets up Quarto
3. Renders the website
4. Deploys it to GitHub Pages

This means I can focus on writing content, and the deployment happens automatically!

## The Result

The end result is a clean, professional website that combines my academic CV with a blogging platform. The site is:

- **Fast**: Static HTML loads quickly
- **Responsive**: Works on all devices
- **Easy to update**: Just edit markdown files and push
- **Professional**: Clean academic styling
- **Extensible**: Easy to add new pages or features

## Conclusion

Creating an academic website doesn't have to be complicated. With Quarto and GitHub Pages, you can have a professional online presence up and running in under an hour. The combination of simplicity, power, and automatic deployment makes this an ideal solution for academics who want to focus on research and writing rather than web development.

If you're interested in creating your own Quarto website, check out the [official Quarto documentation](https://quarto.org/docs/websites/).
